title: 108_hr1835
content: The "National Security Readiness Act of 2003" may be cited as the Act. It addresses military readiness and the conservation of protected species. The "National Security Readiness Act of 2003" amends the Endangered Species Act by changing the designation of critical habitat and limiting the designation of critical habitat on lands controlled by the Department of Defense. The "National Security Readiness Act of 2003" amends the Endangered Species Act by addressing special management considerations, consultation requirements, and the Department of Defense's obligation to comply with species protection laws. Additionally, it modifies the consideration of critical habitat designation by including the impact on national security. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to redefine harassment as any act that injures or disturbs marine mammals in the wild, causing disruption of natural behavioral patterns. SEC. 4. EXEMPTION OF ACTIONS NECESSARY FOR NATIONAL DEFENSE. Section 101 of the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to allow the Secretary of Defense to exempt Department of Defense actions from compliance with the Act if necessary for national defense, with exemptions lasting up to 2 years and renewable. The Secretary of Defense can exempt Department of Defense actions from the Marine Mammal Protection Act for national defense reasons, after conferring with relevant Secretaries and determining the necessity. Each exemption is effective for up to 2 years. SEC. 5. INCIDENTAL TAKINGS OF MARINE MAMMALS IN MILITARY READINESS ACTIVITY. Section 101(a)(5) of the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to exempt the Secretary from publishing notice for incidental takings during military readiness activities authorized by the Secretary of Defense. The Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 is amended to exempt the Secretary from publishing notice for incidental takings during military readiness activities authorized by the Secretary of Defense. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE RESPONSIBILITY FOR CIVILIAN WATER CONSUMPTION IMPACTS ON CRITICAL HABITAT OR ENDANGERED SPECIES. The section limits the Department of Defense's responsibility for civilian water consumption impacts on critical habitat or endangered species. It clarifies that water consumption on military installations or under direct control of the Department of Defense is not considered agency action under the Endangered Species Act. Military installations can voluntarily mitigate water use, and key terms are defined. The term "water consumption" is defined as the use of water for various human purposes. This section applies to Department of Defense actions requiring consultation under the Endangered Species Act after the enactment of this Act.
